There‚Äôs always someone who fails to read the instructions in the clues:

‚ÄúI‚Äôm so eager to get home and make that triple cheese pizza‚Äù
‚ÄúOh get your mind out of the GRATER‚Äù

Our cat adoption agency uses a PETSIT as a precursor to a license to adopt; we want to make sure the human is good enough.

That one stegosaurus is such a wuss about the cold - his tail is SOCKED.

Well, some inventive clergy have used the BARHOP as a way of meeting potential new parishioners.

I‚Äôve been too tired and busy to comment much this week because my 5 year old grandson has been visiting for the week without his parents.  He keeps my wife and me on the go all day. So, I‚Äôve been crashing as soon as I finish the puzzle.  I had to pop in tonight to say how much I suffered by entering Handler instead of PERETTI, of whom I had never heard.  Oh, and I liked the trick of the puzzle as well.

The theme, while not novel, was tricky and well-executed.

But, OCTOPI doesn't belong in crosswords without a 'var.' note, and names shouldn't cross (PERETTI and TAIO)

6.5/10

P.S. I'm aware of the 'octopuses', 'octopodes', 'octopi' usage debate.

Another puzzle comes down to trial and error, gaming the app by entering a series of letters because I don‚Äôt happen to know who Chelsea PERETTI or TAIO Cruz are ‚Äî but the constructor decided their best option was to allow two proper nouns to intersect.
Just the right kind of Thursday clever.
Nope. Didn't get it at all. Way above my pay grade.

I see it now.  But where I live it‚Äôs called ‚Äúgetting your mind out of the gutter‚Äù not GRATER.  So there was nothing to change there.  That threw me for a loop.  Figured out the trick when I got to BARHOP.  

Very clever.  Still trying to figure out how Stegasaurus tail is something other that Plated.

I got through this one, finally, and my last chore was to change from one pair of subbed letters to the other pair of subbed letters for each theme answer.

Before taking out the UT of GUTTER and putting in the RA for GRATER, I was so sure that the theme answers worked that way that I actually checked my entire grid for unrelated typos. I didn't find anything, although those gobbledygook downs at the theme letters were making it hard to figure them out.

Finally, I did substitute in the RA for the UT and the others, and got the little jingle.  But to me, it didn't make sense.

RAT OUT was, for example, the instruction to answer 22A.  So the clue for 22A is [Proverbial bad thing to have your mind in], so the answer is GUTTER.  To get it to GRATER, you go from UT to RA, not the other way around.  But the "hint" in the previous answer said RA to UT.

The others followed the same way.

It seemed to me that it was all bass-ackwards.  The clue should have been for GRATER, and the printed answer should have been GUTTER (with different down answers that made sense with the U and the T).  And so forth for the others.

Or the whole puzzle should have been constructed with the UT to RA order.

I think the theme would have worked better if the directions weren‚Äôt ambiguous. Like instead of cluing to ‚Äúgutter‚Äù when the answer is GRATER, it could have been clued to ‚Äúgrater‚Äù when the answer is GUTTER. When I see ‚Äú__ to __‚Äù I‚Äôm expecting to end up with the second pair of letters, but here we ended up with the first.

On the plus side, I‚Äôm sure I was in the very small minority of people who knew PARADEREST off the top of my head. High school marching band coming in handy out of nowhere!

Trivial nitpick:  I feel like the theme clues should have been clued the other way round, or else worded differently -- if the "instruction for answering" says XX to YY , I expect the clue to fit the XX one and the fill to be the YY one. "Instruction for parsing" would work as fill-to-clue.

But I like the trick :)

Also my brain wants to parse the last lines together: Mike Reese weds Ibex Popup.  They arranged for a bishop but the instructions got confused so it was a bar hop instead, as the entire wedding played The Floor Is Lava (and 18A looks for his sewing case again)

Managed to complete it in 38 mins., using the crosses for the weird answers, but even when finished I could not figure the trick or the weird answers until I came here.  (e.g., I thought "BAR HOP" referred to hops used to make beer, linking to 51A; and some other odd ideas...).  Clever puzzle.

APSES (and naves) are words I vaguely remember from when I took AP Art History 20 years ago, but ones that are far more ingrained now from the XW than they were after I finished that semester...

Not sure how to feel about this puzzle. I enjoyed figuring out the theme and completed the puzzle without lookups. But as others have said, and probably many more will say, the theme clues were backwards. If you're going from something to something else, then the from would be what's already there and the to is what it gets changed to. (GUTTER changes to GRATER, but the clue says RA to UT.)

Most of the fill was very easy for me. In fact, at first I thought it was way too easy until I got to the PERETTI/TAIO/PARADEREST/CLE business. Of course, I was thinking handler like most everyone else, but ruled it out because of several crosses I knew for sure were right. 

So, I just started changing letters until I got to something that seemed to make sense. TAIO seemed like the most likely name since I already had the I and O. PaRETTI sounded like a good Italian name. With no idea about the sportsball team, CLa seemed just as good as anything else. And PARADEREST, which I'd never heard of, made sense when I stopped thinking about a person's role and figured it might have something to do with RESTs in music, which is where you don't play anything.

But ... No finished message. So I ran the alphabet on the first letter of TAIO. Nope. Changed it back to T. Started to flyspeck the rest of the puzzle and found I'd put rIB instead of BIB for Chest Guard. Still not done. That's when I ran the alphabet on the second letter in PERETTI and finally finished!

Was anyone else surprised by MIKE for microphone instead of MIc? I looked it up after finishing the puzzle. Apparently, MIKE was the original abbreviation for microphone, and it's only been changed to MIc in the past 25 years. This article explains why MIKE is actually the better choice. https://www.mentalfloss.com/article/66196/microphone-mic-or-mike

I‚Äôll join in the choir and say that while I had no trouble with the puzzle‚Äôs theme, it did irk me a bit that the wording was ‚ÄúInstruction for answering ____‚Äù when in fact the direction only makes sense as an instruction for *interpreting* the answer of _____. Ex, we are not changing X to Y when we write the answer, we are changing X to Y when we parse the answer. Feels like a simple thing to fix with verbiage, with zero changes to the actual puzzle.

With that said, it was very very early on that these were flipped, so the gameplay was largely unaffected. I found the puzzle a joy to solve. My hat off to the constructor! I just wish the editors had reworded the theme clues to better reflect the trick.

Octopi isn't the correct plural for Octopus. The correct plural of ‚Äúoctopus‚Äù is ‚Äúoctopuses‚Äù. People often write ‚Äúoctopi‚Äù instead because they assume that the plural noun is formed in the same way as Latin loanwords such as ‚Äúfungus/fungi‚Äù. But ‚Äúoctopus‚Äù actually comes from Greek, where its original plural is ‚Äúoctopodes‚Äù https://oceanconservancy.org/blog/2022/02/01/plural-octopus/

Oh, sweet ‚Äì a classic Thursday puzzle, with a riddle to be cracked, involving something not normally done in a crossword, and with Thursday resistance to make the hill harder to climb.

By the time I saw the TO in RATOUT and the other first-halves of the riddle, I had filled in a good portion of the rest of the grid, but none of the second-halves in full.

That is, the riddle remained unsolved through much of the outing, nagging and pestering, making my brain screw up its forehead deeper and deeper, so that when it finally cracked the mystery, the aha was sensational.

Delaying that aha and making it all the sweeter were no-knows like TAIO, vague clues like [‚ÄúYou‚Äôre in on this?‚Äù], and misdirects like [Silent marching band position], a clue that had me cataloging every marching band member I could think of.

Today's crossword-adjacent trivia:
Caesar's last words, according to Suetonius rather than Shakespeare, were uttered in Greek, rather than Latin. "Kai su, teknon?" "You too, child?"

Apparently, a huge segment of our solving public missed this earworm about 15 years ago: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Vysgv7qVYTo This is a perfect example of how crosswords are easier for people who are more cognizant of the world around them (and don't have to be into everything to know the necessary words). The type of music is not the kind I normally listen to, but somehow I knew it (after a little time spent bringing it back up). It was ubiquitous back in 2010. If you can't do this, everything is going to be a "Natick". I'm one day short of 69, by the way. "I'm too old to know this" is only if you want it to be.

For more on why the plural of "octopus" is not fake-Latin "octopi" but Greek "octopodes" (said by no-one), see my little dissertation on the plurals of English nouns ending in -us: https://oikofuge.com/latin-plurals-ending-in-us/ You could also try out "platypodes", the next time you're in the presence of more than one platypus.

Chess moves. ‚ÄúQueen to King‚Äôs Knight 4.‚Äù

That‚Äôs how I interpret the special instruction. 

I.e., Take this pair of letters, move the pair TO here, and replace what‚Äôs there. 

The frustration today seems to arise from solvers who interpret the instruction as, ‚ÄúChange this pair TO this pair.‚Äù

Both interpretations are valid, especially to chess players  of a certain age (the descriptive notation used in the example gave way to algebraic notation around 1980).

If I solve this puzzle using *just* the vertical clues, then my grid is considered perfectly correct. And I never see, and thus never need, 20A, 28A, 44A and 51A.

On the other hand, if I solve the puzzle using *just* the horizontal clues (temporarily ignoring "... or an instruction for answering"), then I have GUTTER, SPIKED, PERMIT and BISHOP, and my grid is deemed incorrect. 

So, upon failing to get the music, I then decide to look at what I earlier ignored. Thus I look at RATOUT in 20A, which is supposed to instruct me how to properly answer 22A. I look at my incorrect GUTTER and try to figure out how to change RA to UT to make things right. But there's no RA there.

OK, this is my argument that there is indeed something "backwards" about this puzzle's thematic presentation.

Still a great theme, but one wonders if the editorial team presented the theme as well as possible.

I almost cried when I didn't see anyone missing me today, since one of my least favorite words has raised its ugly mantle (that thing that so many people mistakenly think is the "head" of the OCTOPus.) Oh, well -- decloaking for this event, which always creates a ruckus. 

 We go through this every time the execrable OCTOPI appears in a puzzle. As awful as it is, I reluctantly concede that it is a valid plural for a crossword. 

However, my marine biology students learn never to use it. I have to assume that some marine biologist, somewhere, has used this unpleasant plural, but I sure don't know one, and I know several who work with OCTOPUSES. (That's the plural we typically use in normal writing, but in some contexts, OCTOPODES or OCTOPODS  would be appropriate; but only the most annoying pedant who is trying to flex their pedantry would use those in normal speech or writing, and they're generally used to apply to the entire clade of OCTOPUSES as a group.) 

Oh -- and in the culinary world, I believe OCTOPUS can be both singular and plural, similar to how the  plural of FISH can be FISH or FISHES, depending on how many species are in the pan/catch/whatever. 

Come to think of it, biologists also use the same algorithm to pluralize FISH, but I don't think I've heard biologists apply it to OCTOPUS.

Late puzzle find. I've never seen another like this. Hard to describe. A Sunday from April 2, 1995 by Norman S. Wizer with the title "Round Robin." Only two theme answer in that one, but... you'll understand why. Clue and answer for one of them: "Word chain #1 (12 wds., coming full circle)" HOUSEPARTYLINEDRIVEWAYSIDEKICKBACKHANDOVERNIGHTCOURT And it did come full circle. The first part- an across: HOUSEPARTYLIN but at the N it turned down. And that line was: NEDRIVEWAYSIDEKICK but that was a down answer. And then at last Letter -K, it turned back to the left so that section was; ODNAHKCABKCIK So the implied there was that in reverse: KICKBACKHANDO And the last one went back up to the beginning letter of the first one, so the implied answer was: OVERNIGHTCOURT (going up). And the other theme was on a 'square' setting inside that first answer. The actual implied answer was: BOATYARDARMCHAIRPOSTROADSHOW But of course it followed the same pattern as the first one going... across, and then down, and across to the left and finally up. Odd one. Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=4/2/1995&g=28&d=A ....

Probably everyone is about done commenting, but I'll make one more stab at explaining why the theme seemed so logical as I solved.

First, there was an "instruction for answering." I knew that 22A was GUTTER but figured there was some different way that needed to be entered because I had not used any special instruction yet. So I filled in all of the right sides of the theme to fit the clues as written, as provisional fill until I could suss out the theme. 

Some of the Downs didn't make sense, but I skipped those letters whenever I hit one of my provisional Acrosses.

My second time through the Across clues, I saw immediately that the last two letters in each left side theme also appeared in the right side. So that suggested interpreting the left side instruction as "move XX to YY" on the right side. Not "change XX to YY," because that wouldn't make sense.

The theme made use of the fact that the verb was implicit. "Move" or "map" works, "change" does not.

@PuzzleWeazel ‚ÄúThe current champion in the Battle of Troublesome Pluralization is octopus, which, depending on which dictionary is consulted, may be written in three different ways: octopi, octopuses, and octopodes. Such a range of options might prompt even the most patient learner of the language to say "What the heck? C'mon, English, get your act together." This state of affairs is not so much the fault of the English language as it is of the people who speak it, who have been debating the proper way to pluralize octopus for a very long time. An article from over 140 years ago, "Octopus Philology" (titled in the clickbait of that era) offers three possibilities, admittedly sneering at two of them.‚Äù https://www.merriam-webster.com/grammar/the-many-plurals-of-octopus-octopi-octopuses-octopodes For a puzzle that includes a reference to the many fabricated words of Lewis Carroll, a light touch may be in order. @PuzzleWeazel All those marine biologists are suffering from TCS (Too Close Syndrome). All the major dictionaries list OCTOPI as a plural of octopus. Here's one: https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/octopus Marine biologists are great at learning how sea creatues evolve, but it takes a linguist to understand how language evolves. While "octopuses" is "supposed to be" the correct plural, many years ago people started saying OCTOPI as well. If enough people say it, it becomes accepted. Old schoolers don't like it, but that's how it is. Now within the field of marine biology, if someone calls them OCTOPI, he might be laughed out of his bathyscaphe, but in general usage, OCTOPI is both common and accepted. Perfect example of TCS.

Interestingly, here is what MW says:

The three plurals for octopus come from the different ways the English language adopts plurals. 

Octopi is the oldest plural of octopus, coming from the belief that words of Latin origin should have Latin endings. 

Octopuses was the next plural, giving the word an English ending to match its adoption as an English word.

 Lastly, octopodes stemmed from the belief that because octopus is originally Greek, it should have a Greek ending.
